subject: Re: [junit] Javadocing test case and other test classes?
msgSnippet: ... That wasn t purposeful.  I thought you were trying to test that multiple customer purchase order entries could be created for one sales order line.  In
messageBody:
On Jan 5, 2005, at 11:50 AM, Kevin Klinemeier wrote:

>
> On Wed, 5 Jan 2005 11:20:48 -0700, Mike Clark <mike@...>
> wrote:
>> I try to arrange my test case classes around common text fixtures.
>> One
>> side effect of doing that is it gives me an extra layer of context (a
>> namespace) on top of the test method name. So, given my limited
>> knowledge of your problem domain, I might have a test case like this:
>>
>> public class OneSalesOrderLineTest extends TestCase {
>>
>> public void setUp() {
>> // fixture for one sales order line
>> }
>>
>> public void testCreateMultipleCustomerPurchaseOrderEntries() {
>> }
>>
>> public void testSomethingElseAboutOneSalesOrderLine() {
>> }
>> }
>
> Close, except I don't make the mistake you've (purposefully) made
> here, including the 'multiple' test with the 'oneLineItem' test.

That wasn't purposeful. I thought you were trying to test that
multiple customer purchase order entries could be created for one sales
order line. In retrospect, you're probably testing the inverse of
that. The example is arbitrary, and I think we're on the same page
here anyway.

>> Does using a separate test case help with the ambiguity?
>
> I'm not sure what you mean here. I'm trying to disambiguate this
> testcase with another testCase that is named similarly:
>
> testMultipleCustomerPurchaseOrderEntriesForManySalesOrderLinesWithDupli
> cates();

If I recall, you also have another test method of this name:

testMultipleCustomerPurchaseOrderEntriesForOneSalesOrderLine()

Both of these have a common base name:
MultipleCustomerPurchaseOrderEntries. Often this is trying to tell me
that I'm missing a a test case class, for example,
TestMultiplePurchaseOrderEntries. That class would include tests for
multiple purchase order entries.

Or, to invert it the other way, perhaps I need two different test case
classes: OneSalesOrderLineTest and ManySalesOrderLines. Each of those
classes would include a test method called
testMultipleCustomerPurchaseOrderEntries(), for example.


>> I often use that technique, as well. By writing out prose, I find
>> words that I'd like to use in the test method name.
>
> True, and most often I do the same thing. But there are cases where I
> felt that the prose held more information than the method name I came
> up with. I'd already written the prose, so I left it to guide me in
> the implementation, and describe the situation to the maintainers.

That sounds reasonable.

> I think folks are overstating my intentions a bit: I'm *not* saying
> that *all* tests need javadoc documentation, I'm not even saying that
> most of them do. The only point I'm making is that occasionally you
> need it, and not shipping the javadoc (the original question) makes
> that occasional-but-important information unavailable to whoever is
> using the unit tests.

I hear you, and I agree.

If by "shipping the JavaDoc" you mean not shipping the HTML that the
'javadoc' tool produces, then I'm simply saying that the
occasional-but-important information is still available in plain text.

Which leads back to the original question about distributing JavaDoc
for test classes. I don't deliver it because my tests generally don't
include JavaDoc tags, and in the rare case they did, a maintainer still
has access to the information in the test source. When I distribute a
library, I do include the JavaDoc for its API. Readers of that
information seem to me to be a different audience altogether.
